ironic_python_agent/hardware.py.message: I have one concern here, we already have reports that on some hardware architectures, in some cases, ipmitool can hang. While this code makes sense, it is a risk which we may be making worse. Just thinking outloud really.
I wonder if it'll cause a problem that get_bmc_address() calls these too. I suggest we try and only do the IPMI module loading once.
I'll be honest, I don't think it's ideal that we're relying on the modprobe idempotence instead of implementing it ourselves in the code; but I won't block the code for that reason.

I intended to keep the methods able to run standalone and independent of the order they are called in.

To my knowledge, modprobe(1) is idempotent, so I don't expect any issues here.
Since there is already an option that bmc_mac won't be present, I'd rather return None or even raise IncompatibleHardwareMethodError

Returning the zero MAC would have the advantage of being able to differentiate between "bmc_mac is not supported by IPA" and "the BMC has no valid LAN interface". Now that I write it out loud I realize that you can detect the lack of a valid LAN interface already by looking at bmc_address. So yeah, I'm gonna return None or somesuch.

releasenotes/notes/bmc-mac-introspection.message: Actually, since you implement it in GenericHardwareManager, there will always be an implementation
Thanks for the clarification, I'll remove the remark :).

No, it's actually an anti-pattern to derive from GenericHardwareManager. But IPA uses *all* hardware managers to route a call, not just the one with the highest priority. Meaning, GenericHardwareManager is always used as a fall-back.
Is it a requirement somehow to derive from GenericHardwareManager? I assumed that implementations may exist which only derive from HardwareManager.

I wonder if exec_ commands would raise Exceptions in such cases? Should not they?

I tried this on a container that was restarting. If the create fails we might get:

docker.errors.APIError: 409 Client Error: Conflict ("Container dc8e4f1ffb557467550e56dba70384a8ec43d47d9a128f8010a3447bd0e96bb8 is restarting, wait until the container is running")

And if the start fails we might get:

docker.errors.NotFound: 404 Client Error: Not Found ("No such exec instance: e1bd89199832388fd7d5f3ff46ad73319a9e2e4fab9f29e32c2c6df17127974c")

I expect inspect would be similar. I think we should try to be fairly open to these kinds of issues to avoid getting wedged.

docker run --restart unless-stopped --name foo centos:8 sleep 2

zuul/zk/merger.py.message: Curious why you decided to switch from /zuul/merge-results* to /zuul/merger/results. Note the extra 'r' at the end of merge. I don't really think it matters much one way or another, but was wondering if that was intentional for some reason.

Two part question:

1) Why change "merge" to "merger"?  Symmetry with executor.
2) Why move "results" under "merger"?  Keep the ZK tree tidy.  Especially once we have a job queue per zone, I wanted everything for a queue under a single root.

So when you ls /zuul you'll see: [executor, merger, keystore, components, ...]
Then under merger: [requests, results, ...]
And under executor:
  * unzoned
    * requests
    * results
    * ...
  * zones
    * foo
      * requests
      * results
      * ...
Ack

zuul/driver/git/gitconnection.py.message:
This calls the method on line 67 of this file.  We do use needs_results above.  Basically, a merge request has 2 modes of operation:

* needs_results=False: the typical asynchronous request to merge a change in a pipeline and produce the results so zuul can proceed with a build.  The result of the merge will be placed in the pipeline results queue.
* needs_results=True: either the git driver or the configloader performing a synchronous merge request to find out something about a repo immediately.  In that case, there is no pipeline results queue for the request; instead the result will be placed in ZK and the merger api will return a future object which will contain the result after wait() completes.

Having said all that, we could probably infer needs_results from whether a buildset was provided with the requests, but this seems good for now.
This is where we call getChangeFilesUpdated and we don't pass in needs_results. We also don't use needs_results above. Was the change above initially necessary and now no longer used?
I don't know why but I read needs_result as an argument to getChangeFilesUpdated and not to getFilesChanges. Sorry for the confusion here.

This might be a good place to be clear when we pass an event or when we pass an event_id. The old code seemed to get an event here which it then passed the event_id of to submitJob(). But now we seem to pass the event the whole way through?

Is that ok for the annotated logger? will it handle both types?

We're not changing what's passed to submitJob; instead we're removing zuul_event_id from the payload for the job.

I think what Felix is doing here is streamlining the code by putting the event id outside of the job parameters (but still it will be included in the request data).  Then if you check the merger server update in this change, it pulls the event id from the merge request instead of the payload.
Ah got it, I see now that the event.zuul_event_id was passed via data and then event was also passed. I agree this is better.

I'm having a hard time understanding this comment. Above it is stated that this request is by definition unlocked. I don't understand where there would be an is_locked() check that can fail if it wasn't already unlocked?

Separately we seem to acquire a scheduler cleanup lock before calling this method which should mean no other cleanups are running at the same time. This means we can only race the mergers?

We only call this function if the merge request is unlocked.

But a lost merge request is defined as "a merge request in running state that is unlocked".

We check the state first, then we check the lock.  The following sequence can produce the error (prefixed by thread id for clarity):

* [1] merge job is locked and in running state
* [2] findLostMergeRequests lists all the merge jobs
* [2] it performs a get on our merge job [note 1]
* [2] it observes the state is "running"
* [1] the merger finishes and updates the merge job state "completed"
* [1] the merger unlocks the merge job
* [2] findLostMergeRequests checks the lock on our merge job and sees it unlocked
* [2] findLostMergeRequests declares the job lost
* [2] this method updates the merge job to set it to "completed", using the zstat from the previous get (note 1 above)
* [2] the update produces a BadVersionError because the zstat doesn't contain the latest node version

Therefore we know we should ignore this job.
Got it this helps a bunch thanks.

zuul/merger/server.py.message:
If we unlock before deleting, we definitely need to update the state, otherwise another merger could start processing this.

However, we can delete before unlocking, which will avoid that case and be more efficient.

There could still be a case where the merger crashes after submitting the complete event and before deleting.  We can ignore that case (there will be a duplicate result) or we write the result, delete, and even unlock all within a transaction.

The name "MergerWorker" is a bit confusing.  Previously, the Merger was implemented as a gearman Worker, so that's why the "worker" was started by the "merger".

But now we really just have the main merger thread; there aren't two distinct components.  I think we can drop the word "worker" from ewherewhere it's used (or maybe in some cases, like self.merger_worker change it to self.merger_thread).
Disregard this comment, the check after we enter the iterator is sufficient.
We should check if we're running after the wait, otherwise we might pick up a job (if one arrives just after we are requested to stop).

There is no exception handling within the merger thread, so if any job raises an exception, the thread will exit.  Previously, the gearman worker handled that for us, but now we need to do it.

Basically, any exception in self._runMergerWorker (which I suggest renaming to _runMergeJob) should still report completion (but also, failure).  And separately, if that report has an error, it should log it and continue.  The thread should never exit unless explicitly requested.

It's possible this is what's causing the test errors, but I still haven't caught it in logs.
See comment on earlier PS.
I think the easiest thing to do is to just set an internal flag.  Below in runMerger, we would just "continue" after clearing the wake event if the pause flag is set.
I uploaded a followup to do that.
No, the merger doesn't know anything about the executor.  The executor pauses its internal merger when it is paused (but it doesn't pause it when it stops accepting jobs).
Ok, so we can just remove this todo here
Might consider setting this flag immediately before starting the thread below. This way there is less time where the thread is not running but the flag is set?
Or remove this join in favor of the one below?

Right, other places call it.

To shut down a merger:

merger.stop()
merger.join()

Same is true for the executor.

Well, the reason we have stop and join separate is so that when we shut down, we can stop() everything and the join() everything; that way shutdown is parallel, not serial.  That's why I think we should drop this join and keep the one below.
Why not replace this with self.join() or remove the join def below?
Got it.
I think I may be confused now. What join call below? We define a join method but MergeServer.stop() doesn't seem to call it?
Yup basically we should call self.join() here I think.
Is this worthy of logging? We will skip the merge request on the assumption something else has the lock and is handling it. Might be painful to debug lost merges if we don't record this?
We probably could; it would be a little verbose.  But this is the same behavior in the executor and we haven't needed it there yet.  I think I'd prefer to wait and see if we need to add it.
Ok

I agree.  It is worth noting that if the ZK connection disappears, so will our lock, so we don't need to worry about that.  But if there's some sort of error that we accidentally don't handle lower in the call stack then we could leak the lock.  So better safe than sorry.

The executor actually handles this by adding the unlock in the equivalent of the runMerger method.  We should do that here.

I think these calls can raise as they interact with zookeeper. If they raise we will not unlock the lock we grabbed above.

Perhaps we should run everything after the lock acquisition in the try block?
This was corrected in ps14

I have a slight preference for maintaining symmetry with the lock and unlock calls if we can. I know completeMergeJob does the unlock but moving that here would make it clearer to see we are unlocking.

I think if we structure this like we do the executor, it will be robust and easy to follow.  It won't be exactly symmetrical here, but I think we can handle it.

I'd at least like this change to be structured like the executor, and then if we don't like that, maybe we can change both simultaneously in a followup?
Keeping the two in sync makes sense to me. We can update in followups if we have a preference change.
Does the length of the serialized json object tell us something that None or not None wouldn't?
Yep.

Yes, the objective of this log line was to track down the problem caused by writing packets that were too large to ZK.  (The issue we just fixed with the sharding changes.)

Maybe we don't need it now, but this change isn't changing that, it's just retaining the existing logging.
Got it. And I agree this isn't changing the old log behavior but now we check against None above. I thought maybe we were looking for 0 vs not 0 length but we are looking for small vs large instead.
Different data; different level.  I'm happy to revisit these, but this log message is also just retained in this change, this isn't a change.
Seems like this log message provides far more info than the one above.
Can we move this into a finally block and drop the finally block call in _runMergeJob()? Then we aren't tracking two places we can call completeMergeJob() through.
We could, but it's not straightforward -- this is exactly equivalent to what we already did in the executor, and I'd like to keep them in sync.
Ok
When we have the pipeline state in zk I think it makes sense to put the repo state directly there instead of forwarding it through multiple copies via events.

What requires a result?  How do leaks get cleaned?  Can they be large enough to require sharding?
Results may be required by synchronous operations like cat jobs and file change jobs.  Some thoughts:

1) We need to be able to clean up leaked results in the case that the calling scheduler crashes.
2) The results can be quite large, and we should accomodate sharding.

To address #1, we could add an ephemeral node to indicate that we're waiting on a result.  It would be natural to consider pre-creating the result node as an ephemeral node, but once we consider #2 and that the result may require sharding, we must remember that we can't create children under an ephemeral node.

In short, these would be the paths:

/zuul/merge-requests/abcdef: the merge request object; deleted as soon as request completed
/zuul/merge-results/abcdef: the result object for merge request abcdef, written to only if a result is required
/zuul/merge-result-waiters/abcdef: an ephemeral node indicating there is a scheduler waiting on the results of abcdef

A cleanup thread could look for merge-results/abcdef and iff there is not merge-result-waiters/abcdef, delete it.

The scheduler waiting for the result would need to delete the waiter znode when it has received the result.

Yes, we may.  The scheduleMerge method accepts the repo state as input, and that can be quite large.

It's probably simplest to just copy what we're doing for the executor api now.  We could consider moving both of them to only shard when necessary (as we do with events), which could save some time.

cliff/help.py.message: What's going on with this private property?

So note that this is not a property that is defined by the stdlib argparse module.

It's one that autopage.argparse applies to the parser so it can keep track internally of whether it's safe to colourise the output (whether it's safe to depends on whether we are outputting to a terminal or not) in ColorHelpFormatter:
https://github.com/zaneb/autopage/blob/main/autopage/argparse.py#L141-L142

If you use the built in _HelpAction, autopage.argparse handles this itself:
https://github.com/zaneb/autopage/blob/main/autopage/argparse.py#L122-L124

However, in this case we're writing our own HelpAction that does other stuff in addition to parser.print_help(), and so we end up having to duplicate some of the internal implementation from autopage because there's no way to just inherit it.
I made a new release with a public API for this.
A comment with those details would help future maintainers.
Is `color` a bool? Would it make sense to call it `using_color` to express that?

nova/tests/functional/test_nova_manage.p.message:
This is now two days past what it originally was. I'm not sure I get the logic, and it seems like the nested time fixture above is really the fix for the issue you describe. Was this left in intentionally?

Doesn't hurt and isn't wrong, I don't think, just not related to the failure to reset the time when used nested-ly, as described (AFAICT).

Okay, I guess I'm not sure why we'd want this (or any) test to be at all dependent on the actual time the test is being run. The fact that you can change the behavior by setting your clock incorrectly means it's not properly insulated, IMHO.

The reason this test depends on time is because, without mocking any database calls, we can only cause multiple task_log records to be generated by advancing time past the last completed audit period:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/72c8722e09a47794fc5412a14587a74e79195fca/nova/compute/manager.py#L9539-L9541

It checks whether a record exists for the utils.last_completed_audit_period() and if one does, it will not write a new record.

In retrospect, maybe I should have mocked the return values of utils.last_completed_audit_period() to make multiple records be written instead of overriding time. I wanted to test that using --before would archive only a subset of the total records, so I wanted multiple task_log records to be written.

With regard to the change in the 'days' for testing --before, once the time override restoration was done, the value of --before became 2021-08-01 (2021-07-01 + 31) and the updated_at for the first record is also 2021-08-01, so adding only 31 days exactly would archive nothing for "before 2021-08-01". With the bug present (using real utcnow), --before always ended up being later than the first updated_at timestamp of 2021-08-01, so it always archived one record.

If I remove the +1 (and set the system clock back to 07.31) then this test fails. So I think this is part of the fix. I think it is about the > instead of >= relation between the task to be archived and the current date. Only adding exactly 31 day to "today" make the first task creation date equal to the value of --before. Simply adding a single second  (datetime.timedelta(days=31, seconds=1)) is enough to make the test pass.

cert-rotation/templates/bin/_rotate-cert.message: This looks awfully dangerous deleting all the pods in a loop. If the cycle time is long, the service is guaranteed to be taken down by this cron job. The rotation should be a "rolling upgrade" to avoid service disruption.
++, the old certificate should still be good, so a rolling restart would be better here IMO to avoid any disruptions.

How are secrets mounted? If they are not mounted as volume subpath, pods need not be deleted.
Also, deleting pods may cause data loss for applications. And, in some cases, pods may need to be deleted in order.
They are mounted as subpaths inside the containers. So the pod needs to be restarted.
If they are just mounted as volumes, K8S takes care of refreshing the secret inside the pod.

All the secrets are mounted as volumes.

Ideally, deleting pods should be idempotent and sequence is not required. It is not redeployment, it is just restarting the pods. Its like the pods restarting on regular basis. Yes, when rotating the certificates, there may be disruption in service, but that is expected. Running of cron can be configured/disabled based on the deployment requirements.
Shouldn't the cert-manager clear the secrets when the certificate is reissued when the certificate owns the secret ref?

We are deleting the secret here and not the certificate (CRD). The secret contain tls.crt, tls.key and ca.crt. Once this secrete is delete, certificate (CRD) will recreate the secret with renewed tls.crt expiry. Certificate (CRD) once deleted is not recreated automatically.
should we only add the certificate to secretsToRotate when the rotate condition is true?
No. The logic is we need to create a list of all certificates so we can rotate them even if one cert has expired.
typo

should all this logic consider renewBefore by the cert-manager? specifically this is rotating things in a different schedule from what the cert manager will rotate its own cert cert.

   spec:
     # Secret names are always required.
     secretName: example-com-tls
     duration: 2160h # 90d
     renewBefore: 360h # 15d

.status.renewalTime is based on .spec.renewBefore in Certifcates. The default value is 15 days. cert-manager automatically renews certificate before expiry and updates the Certificate and Secret resources without restarting them.

The value of date corresponding to rotateBefore (in this script) has to be less than .status.renewalTime else this cron job will never rotate the certificates and restart the pods (for new certificates to take effect) because the certs would have automatically been rotated by the cert-manager and the comparison on line 33 will never be true.

Even if we just go by .status.renewalTime or .spec.renewBefore (and not take rotateBefore as input as config) and let cert-manager automatically renew the certs, we still need to restart the pods so that the new certificates can take effect. For this, .status.lastTransitionTime of Certificate can be compared with the .status.lastScheduleTime of this cron job and if later is less, than restarts the pods. Here secrets do not need to be deleted to get renewed. But issue here if a pods restarts after the cert was renewed but before the cron was run, the pods will mount the new certs. In this case, there may be a mis-match of certs on this pods and on old pods and SSL handshake can fail. 

So I think the safest bet would be to go with rotateBefore and have it set greater than .spec.renewBefore or 15 days when configuring.
renewBefore field is set by default in all regular certificates but not in ingress certificates. So may not be a good idea on relying on this field.
Is the logic needed to differentiate whether certificates have been rotated by cert-manager, and not deleting the secrets for those? or the secrets need to be deleted regardless?
That logic is in line 51-53 in which case only pods are rotated and not cert/secrets.

secretsToRotate is being used for both cases. When rotateSecrets is true, is it guaranteed that secretToRotate will not have any cert/secrets which are added by logic in line 51-53? It's not clear these cases are mutually exclusive within the same loop on 37.

not an expert issue, but is it "normal" that the cert-manager would not have rotated the certs past is rotateBefore days?   Is this just kind of like a fail-safe?  Should we fully expect cert-manager to do its job mostly?

rotateBefore is number of days before the expiry that a user wants certificates to be rotated. Whenever the certificates are rotated, values of keys notAfter and notBefore in the certificate is updated. Once the certs are rotated due to if on line 40, notAfter would have changed so the cert-maanger will not rotate the certificate.
is there a need to check if "--enable-certificate-owner-ref" is enabled?  would the script need to handle deleting of secrets otherwise?

From cert-manager documentation "If you would prefer the Secret to be deleted automatically when the Certificate is deleted, you need to configure your installation to pass the --enable-certificate-owner-ref flag to the controller."
Cert-manager creates 2 resources certificate and secret. Certificate has all the information about the certificate and secret has CA, cert and key. When cert-manager rotates the certificates, it updates the cert in the secret and certificate is not deleted and hence the secret is not deleted. Note in line 47, we are deleting secret and not certificate. Once the secret is deleted cert-maanger creates a new secret with new cert automatically.
vs just go ahead and sleep 30s just in case?  is there any harm?
Yes we can, but what's the point of sleeping if the secrets were never deleted, so what are we really sleeping for?
Consider avoid using global vars if feasible i.e. deleteAllSecrets could be passed as parm true/false to the function, list could be returned by function....
Correction, In bash script data structures can not be returned, hence the global are defined.
In bash script you can not pass the data structures as function parameters hence the global are defined.
NIP: be consistent whether to use shortname to retrieve the resources.
If the execution continues, perhaps flagging it as WARNING, instead or ERROR.
I want it as error because this is an error for the cert that is not rotated and may be in a bad state. It is for the other secrets that were successfully rotated the process needs to continue.
typo
Noted and will be updated in next PS

cert-rotation/values.yaml.message: I am not sure about having this run monthly by default. I am curious if people will make sure to override this, otherwise they may notice all their infrastructure fall apart at 2am when the month ticks over and someone will get a late night phone call.

But default value of max_days_to_expiry: 60 which means if the cron job run within 60days of expiry (which it will as by default run every 30 days), the certificates will be rotated. So the certificates will not expire.

Can you explain what happens if a certificate expires on the 17th of a month? On the first of month - it is > max_days_to_expiry so it is not rotated, but it won't be rotated until next month and the certs are not valid between 17th and the start of the month. Is that an accurate assessment with this default setting?

Yes. So when the certs expires on 17th, the cert-manager will automatically rotate the certs, but the pods would have not restarted hence new certificates would have not come into affect. So yes in this time, the certs that are mounted on the pods would have expired. max_days_to_expiry should be 60 as I originally had or 45. 
When the cron-job run next on the 1st of the month, it identifies certs have been rotated and will restart the pods.

consider adding something like this .. it might be nice to create the job as a "template" and later run `kubectl create job --from cronjob/cert-rotate`

    jobs:
      rotate:
        suspend: false

BFD can be used to detect faults in the bidirectional path between two entities.   Typically the entities on either sides can be routers,  bgp-routing-protocol engine, ospf-routing-protocol-engine etc.


The idea of this Spec is to provide a generic Tenant driven BFD Monitoring Service function in Neutron which can be put to use for the following purposes by other Neutron Specs (and / or backend implementations of Neutron):


a. Use BFD monitoring with Neutron Extra Route API , to provide intelligent forwarding plane for Extra Route Destinations configured for Neutron Routers

b. Use BFD monitoring with Neutron BGPaaS Peering API, to provide intelligent forwarding plane for Peers configured under Neutron Dynamic BGPaaS

C. Use BFD monitoring 

In this Spec, we will focus on resource entities and APIs to cover generic BFD Monitoring Service for Openstack Tenants


In addition to the same, we will also propose enhancement to the Neutron Extra Route API to take advantage of this BFD-Monitoring-aaS, thereby preventing Neutron Routers from blackholing the traffic-flows to to Extra-Route destinations due to "unavailable (or) unreachable nexthops" that may be configured serve such Extra-Route destinations.

Why this is changed to ``address_scope_id``? Could you elaborate the detail sicne I did not see any information about `address scope` in this spec?
Actually it is more like a generalization of the API (see my comment: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/767337/8/specs/wallaby/bfd_support.rst#212 )

address-scope provide an IP-Scoping for the source and destination addresses of a BFD monitor.
Meaning, it makes us possible to derive the subnet mask for the source and the destination addresses.   

Also when two tenants create BFD Monitor with same source and/or destination addresses (eg., overlapping addresses),  the address-scope drives conflict resolution as it represents the IP scope for such source/destination addresses.

Ah yes! some items would not be removed for testcases that created more than one containers. Code has been updated. Thanks!
this can move after wait after L56. wait call is sync call so until it is deleted we will not process next.
Bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1938593 has been created with logs per discussion.

tearDown are run per test case and within one test class, all the test cases run in serial means every test tearDown will be called in serial. Yes, test case tearDown of other test class can be run in parallel but they should not delete the container of other test class.

So basically delete_containers() request will be coming from a test case with either containers created within the test case or created at test class level. There cannot be delete_containers() call which try to delete the containers created in other test class. if so then it is bug in test.

Thanks for the comments. Per observation in the lab, the tearDown for each method is not being called in sync. The tearDown of current method can be called while tearDown of previous method is waiting due to wait_for_resource_deletion. If moving the line as suggested, the subsequent method will likely send extra request to delete same container while is being deleted per request of previous method.

thanks for explaining in bug report, now it is clear to me.

Instead of here deleting, we should delete in class method delete_containers()at L137

here after L142 we can clear the cls.containers list.

     cls.containers = []

ok, so actual issue is how classes are cleaning up the container. The delete operation on container (this method) is supposed to delete all the crated containers at the test class level tearDownClass not at the test level tearDown() which is what few test classes doing and you are seeing the issue

1 https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7e96c8e854386f43604ad098a6ec7606ee676145/tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_services.py#L24

2 https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7e96c8e854386f43604ad098a6ec7606ee676145/tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_acl.py#L34

3 https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7e96c8e854386f43604ad098a6ec7606ee676145/tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_quotas.py#L49

4 https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7e96c8e854386f43604ad098a6ec7606ee676145/tempest/api/object_storage/test_container_acl_negative.py#L45

We need to change the cleanup from tearDown to resource_cleanup(this is called in tearDownClass), like below

    def resource_cleanup(cls):
        cls.delete_containers()
        super(ContainerTest, cls).resource_cleanup()

like done in https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/7e96c8e854386f43604ad098a6ec7606ee676145/tempest/api/object_storage/test_account_quotas_negative.py#L74

If you change it in above 4 test class then it will fix the issue with cleanup at class level.

Thanks for the comments and suggestion. As mentioned in IRC channel, clearing the list of container names here won't solve the race condition, and the change would become unnecessary as the list is being re-initialized. 
Can we make a copy of the list, clear the list, and pass the copy of the list to delete_containers()?

Logs have been provided in the bug to show the race condition where second test/method delete the container which was created by the first test/method.

I'm quite worried that addressing this is going to be even more confusing. As we do not have inheritance baked into these policies this would allow users to blindly change things and not be able to verify that their change actually took effect.

The example you gave is quite extreme as if the policy prevents "get_image" the users would not have any access to images at all. But good example here is for example locations. Lets say user don't have access to list the locations but they would have cd permissions to them. Meaning one would be able to delete and create locations without actually having access to the resource.

So that said, I think we still need to enforce that the user can actually access the resource before allowing them to change it.

> I'm quite worried that addressing this is going to be even more confusing. As we do not have inheritance baked into these policies this would allow users to blindly change things and not be able to verify that their change actually took effect.

But we do have inheritance today, which is the problem. Trying to grant copy-image to a specific "can-copy-images" role is not possible. Why? Because the copy-image operation requires modify-image. Aside from the special case we've implemented around that, these kinds of things lead to the operator having to basically grant full access to an image to do something to it.

We do not inherit read access by granting modify access, we have requirement of read access to the resource you are modifying.

I think this is big enough backwards incompatible change that it's merits should be discussed outside of the refactoring. Also I think it's big enough breakage that it likely should require API major version change. I know breaking the API is trivial in Nova where you can just declare new microversion and once the old behaviour gets too nasty to maintain you stop supporting it but that is not exactly API stability nor work without microversions.
I wholeheartly disagree with this statement. My reasoning above.

The easiest counter example that explains why this is necessary is, IMHO, the delete case.

I may want to write some script that deletes snapshots of a nova instance when it's deleted. That thing reads an audit log that is generated from a consumer of the nova notification queue, or maybe it's looking at snapshot dependencies in Ceph. Regardless, that script just needs to be able to delete things, but not actually see the image and its associated metadata (which includes usernames and software license keys). I only want to grant it the ability to delete images, but nothing else.

You could also have a similar sort of thing with update. Say you've got an agent that is backing up images to tape very slowly in the background. It's doing its work at the RBD level of course, but needs to be able to flag an image with a last-backed-up=$date or tape-number=$n after it is done. You don't need that thing to be able to read the metadata on the image, you just need it to be able to blindly set a key.

Surely there's a case to be made here for upload-image as well. Imagine a case where I'm creating an image record, putting some software license keys in the metadata and then passing off the ID to some bot that is going to construct the actual image data for people and upload it. I don't want to have to put that bot in everyone's project and grant it admin access, I want to define a role for software-uploader-bot, and grant that upload ability across the board, but without any other permissions.

These are clearly not things everyone will need to be able to do, but if you're operation on the principle of least privilege, there's really no reason why we should tell operators that they have to grant those scripts the ability to see everything about the image just to do those things.
This is not great for consistency. I think this should be investigated how much extra work it would actually need to be consistent across the policies.

I actually don't like the word "policies" in here, because IMHO these are business logic decisions. They're glance behaviors, not really policies. They're not override-able, based on who you are, they're fundamental features and thus make sense to be implemented in a fixed way. So, I don't think it's a consistency problem.
AFAIK, we can move all policies closer to the API.

Publicize and Add Member are API operations and should be controlled by relevant policy items. What I meant was "I can see this image because I am a member" should not be controlled by the policy because it is glance-specific logic. "I can see images in shared state (because I am  member)" makes sense as a policy check.

We have policies like publicise image and add member. And I don't see benefits of enforcing them somewhere else than where all the rest of our policies are enforced. Isn't the whole point of this work to get the policy enforcement consistently close to the API?

For not breaking the API as claimed on the REST API Impact section we would need to lean towards the "old" behaviour. Or we need to be honest that we're making breaking changes and then we should honour deprecations, deprecate the old policies and replace them with new ones that behaves differently.

I think that "default to the more secure" is the only reasonable approach here. Every single API call needs to be prepared to hit a 403 at all times. What we're describing here is that potentially a thing that you used to be able to do is suddenly not allowed, which is a lot better default than the opposite. I don't even have an example of what might fall into this bucket, but I think having this as the goal of how to handle such a situation is the right one.

Are you saying that if something is too open today (like the metadef CRUD operations were) that we should default to less secure? The metadef prior art suggests that we should take the approach described here, which is opt to fail secure.

I'm saying that if user is currently able to do X after refactoring the user should be still able to do X. We have clear security bug process how to address cases if as part of this work we realize that something did not provide the security intended. Obviously one could always argue that user not being able to do X is likely more secure than the opposite so we should just lock down everything (and yes there is plenty of examples where deployments consider exposing some features being insecure and not allowing them for the users even if that is not widely agreed).

For this I do expect the user being project member as of RBAC persona, as discussed last cycle we do not have use cases identified for project admin persona and the reader is obviously a new thing that has not existed before. If the scope of said policy does not seem relevan anymore we should deprecate it and propose replacement(s) for it but not redefine it based on opinionated security. Thus lean to the old behaviour and take appropriate process of either security bug or deprecation if we need to change the scope.

Probably I should skip this point from the spec. I have written this considering feature RBAC related changes as well.

Also just for the information, while adoption project scope we already added deprecation note/message to our existing policy rules. So we are following deprecation policy.

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/policies/image.py#L33

This is quite harsh take on the fact that we've given our deployers the promise until now that we do not break their configs over upgrade (valid up to date config in release N should still work equally on N+1). Are we going to drop this promise in favor to make the work easier for us?
I think the point here is, we have already adopted experimental behavior of RBAC project persona with following proper depreciation rules. Deployer should start understanding those in detail.

Aside from "do nothing" what would you suggest here? I'm not really sure what else we can do other than try our best not to break things, flag the potential, and require operators with custom policies to test their stuff.

This to me is a lot like the rootwrap config. It's kind of config, but you can't really change it and expect it to be honored going forward because of how closely tied it is to the internals. The policy file is even worse, since it's a DSL where you could do a lot of unpredictable things that are fragile from release to release.

I'm suggesting that refactoring the code taking care of our policy enforcement should not change the API behaviour. If we identify defaults we should change, that should be discussed outside of the scope of refactoring and done over appropriate deprecation. Main point is that specially overwritten policies from policy file should behave the same as before the refactoring to not break the deployment over upgrade of the code, like we have promised to our admins for years.

My concern with this statement still stands. With point 2. below, this change would be heavily backwards comaptibility breaking change and IMO should not be in the scope of refactoring where the policies are enforced. Being such a fundamental change this probably should require Images API v3.

> Good example of what will break if the get_image and modify_image are not enforced together anymore is our image update calls.
> 
> Client cannot form the json patch at all, and if you hadcraft it either the response will be broken or that specific API will be leaking data as the response for that call is the image metadata in the response body. Including the properties that are read-only in schema or did not get modified in any way.

Leaking what? Whether a key exists or not? TBH, you example here seems to further prove that we do not need to get the key first. If we make a patch call with "add" and we get back a conflict, then if we care, we can make the call again with "change". Whichever returns 20x tells us what we need to know -- that the key was set (added or updated). In most cases that will be one call instead of two to do a get first, but at worst, it will be the same.

Agree that the clients are currently doing the get first and those would fail if an operator configures the policy to prevent it. However, that *also* means that any operator that configures a write-only permission will immediately know that typical users would be impacted since the clients will do a get first, followed by the update. In summary, the client behaviors already kinda give us the get-then-put behavior, so we don't need to also enforce/require that in glance, IMHO.

I think arguing that making the policy _able_ to be more fine-grained should require a new major API version is extreme hyperbole. The default rules will be exactly what people expect, and remain in-line with history. Meaning by default, nobody will be able to update an image they cannot also show. The only change in behavior would be in a place where the operator had written a policy that granted update ability to someone that didn't have get permission, and relied on the fact that we check both to ensure that they can't. I hardly see how that begs an entirely new API major version.

Either way, that situation would be like having 0666 permissions on a file, and making sure people can't write to it because the directory above is missing the --x bit. Such an arrangement would be extremely irresponsible security policy, especially for a cloud.

Good example of what will break if the get_image and modify_image are not enforced together anymore is our image update calls.

Client cannot form the json patch at all, and if you hadcraft it either the response will be broken or that specific API will be leaking data as the response for that call is the image metadata in the response body. Including the properties that are read-only in schema or did not get modified in any way.

I'm sorry I missed the meeting on this topic, but I don't understand exactly how we can have both 2) and 3).


If the get_* policies are no longer enforced when updating/deleting/uploading/downloading images, doesn't that somehow change the behaviour of Glance? What exactly do you mean by "backward compatibility" then?
OK, thanks for explaining things further.

The only behavioral change would be if an operator set the policies for get and update to be different from the default and different from each other. The operator can *already* cause "behavioral change(s)" in glance, according to that definition, by altering the policy. If we allow them to set custom policies at all, then they can alter those behaviors.

I think what Abhi means by backwards compatibility here is that we won't remove or change any policy names (which would totally orphan a chunk of an existing policy) and try to keep the same semantics where possible (i.e. not make update_image suddenly also refer to delete operations, etc). That makes sense to me and I think it makes sense for it to be in the spec here like this.

Like anything else, if we make changes to the backend, then custom things operators are doing may require some review and tweaking. We could say "well, Glance required get_image to do update_image in 2010, so we will forever check get_image *and* update_image when doing an update," but that precludes ever being able to allow operators to actually write policies they think they should be able to write, such as the use-cases I gave in earlier discussion on this spec.

RBAC itself is a big change in behavior across the board, in all projects, and yet it's clearly identified by the larger community of developers and operators and a necessary effort to get ourselves to the point of actually being able to implement a sane security policy. This refactoring is just a step in the way of getting there, and changes like this are going to be required. It's what release notes, upgrade tool checks, etc are for.
As noted on L 57 point 3. of proposed change the RBAC changes are not considered within this spec. So I do not understand why they are deployment impact consideration within the scope of this spec?

glance/gateway.py.message:
I think this is potentially very dangerous change to drop. The hard requirement of being owner or admin is removed we're going to open can of worms that is not easy to clean and getting the read-only repo is good failsafe for anyone implementing changes to really think if they should be doing what they are if this layer is preventing them to proceed.

This would be very fundamental change to the API (allowing permissive policies to overcome the direct ownership/admin requirement) and I think it should be discussed separately from the discussion of where our policies are enforced.

> I think this is potentially very dangerous change to drop. The hard requirement of being owner or admin is removed we're going to open can of worms that is not easy to clean and getting the read-only repo is good failsafe for anyone implementing changes to really think if they should be doing what they are if this layer is preventing them to proceed.
> 
> This would be very fundamental change to the API (allowing permissive policies to overcome the direct ownership/admin requirement) and I think it should be discussed separately from the discussion of where our policies are enforced.

But see, that's the whole point of the RBAC work. The fact that the admin role is special is what makes things so inflexible. That's why other projects have moved away from is_admin to role:admin, and it's why we're having to refactor this stuff for system scope as it is. Having this kind of hard-coded "admin is special" rule is the same reason unix's permission model of having to delegate basically everything to root all the time is such a disaster.

It's also the reason we had to do all the refactoring of the copy-image process to delegate to admin. The desire was to allow some users to copy images that they can *read* to other stores where they can be used more easily. That involves some trivial modification of the image (by glance, on behalf of an otherwise unprivileged user) in order to do that (i.e. just setting the copying-to-stores fields, etc), but they couldn't because of this hard and fast enforcement. So, we basically implemented sudo inside of glance for that feature, which is, as you know, complicated.

If "authorization_layer=True" means that we turn on the legacy layers, shouldn't it default to False? Otherwise in the future, all our calls to get repo will be "get_repo(context, authorization_layer=False)".

While we're at it, maybe we should even name the parameter "legacy_authorization_layer" so make it really really clear that this is a thing of the past.

> If "authorization_layer=True" means that we turn on the legacy layers, shouldn't it default to False? Otherwise in the future, all our calls to get repo will be "get_repo(context, authorization_layer=False)".

It's =True by default because that keeps the existing behavior. As we convert layers above this, we make those pass =False to disable the legacy stuff. After we're all done, we can remove that layer and all the flags. This is intended as transition, and won't live forever.

> While we're at it, maybe we should even name the parameter "legacy_authorization_layer" so make it really really clear that this is a thing of the past.

We could, but since it's not going to live long term, it's not a big deal I think. Making it too long gets annoying and at the moment, the legacy stuff is the more common.

mistralclient/api/base.py.message:
I understand the default value of False was chosen to keep the backward-compatibility, but the previous behavior is potentially dangerous and it must be set to False only when users understand the risk. I am not sure which should be considered first between security consideration and backward-compatibility in this case.

Note that CLI implementation (OSC plugin) load the file contents specified by the command-line argument in the CLI layer and it is not affected even if enforce_raw_definitions is set to True.
Yeah, the question from both of us is "double loading of file contents is an intentional feature or just an unexpected behavior?"

Currently CLI supports loading file path or url from file (I mean creating a text file which has url or file path as its content and specify path of that text file). I understand this would be an odd usage but I hesitated to break the existing usage.

The main cause of this problem was that this code to load arbitrarily contents is executed in server side, but as long as this code is executed in client side (like usage of CLI) it would be much safer.

Only mistral developers know the design intention. IMHO it should be set to True by default for safer defaults (The reason is described above already), but the final decision is up to the mistral team. I have no more word.

Basically this depends on whether the usage I described is intentional one, and I have no strong opinion about it. I'd wait for some more inputs from Mistral core team based on the history they have in their mind.

nit: HTTP_X_PROJECT_ID *

I am not sure about the correct way to talk about these.  From an API client point of view, the header is provided by setting "X-Project-Id" in the request before sending it.  It's the WSGI layer in the server that converts the provided header into the HTTP_X_PROJECT_ID.

I can note both as equivalent in the next patch revision.
Done
would this work even without the owner of the project scoped token being a domain admin.
Ack
Yes. Technically the token is still system-scoped, but we're just letting system users specify a project ID in addition to the system.

Advantages:

- Explicit audit trail via role assignments in keystone
- Ensures that operations on project-owned resources must be done with a project-scoped token

Disadvantages:

- Very chatty and will increase the amount of time it takes for system users to do things with project-owned resources
- Will not work for system-users cleaning up resources in a project that doesn't exist since you can't get a token scoped to a project that doesn't exist
- Could result in a leftover role assignments for system users
- Will not work for system readers since they don't have the ability to create role assignments in keystone (that's a writable operation)
Added these to the spec.

Advantages:

- Less chatty than approach #1 because it doesn't require an explicit assignment
- Ensures that operations on project-owned resources must be done with a project-scoped token

Disadvantages:
- Must be done for each system user on each domain, which are both dynamic resources (e.g., requires a process doc?)
- Potential for privilege escalation if a system reader is given the admin or member role on a domain (what's responsible for this, the deployment tool? the user?)
- Will not work for system readers since they don't have the ability to create role assignments in keystone (that's a writable operation)
nit: role

Also added these.
nit: request headers, right?
KSM should fail if the request has more than one Project ID.  Reasoning: Requests now on inserts a single Project ID because it scrubs any coming in from the user.

Yeah - documenting that limitation here would be a good idea and we can figure out if we should pursue it later.

As we're learning, usage of context.project_id in OpenStack is assuming a single value, not a list. I'm not sure how:

  X-Project-Id: foo
  X-Project-Id: bar

would behave in the wild. I think calling that out here might be useful.

In the short term, operators might need to query for all instances in a project to use the project ID pass through functionality.
I agree, it would be good to call out the limitation of a single Project ID here.

ok so this could work yes.
we may be able to be a little smarter in some case and try and figure it out automatically but explict --os-project-id gets us most of the way there.


it will mean that system admins need to adapt form

openstack --os-cloud admin server stop <uuid>

to 

openstack --os-cloud admin --os-project-id <project> server stop <uuid>

which proably means they have to look up the project id in a previous call
but it gets us 90% of the way there.

yep restricting to one header i think makes sense.

technically i think you can do this today

openstack --os-cloud admin server stop <tenant-1-vm> <tenant-2-vm>

this would not work if we restirct to just one X_PROJECT_ID but again i think
this is an edgecase to an edgecase.

if we find that too limiting we can always extended it after we get feedback on this approach form operators.

Another thing to add here is that we should make sure this is only ever a list of one. Since it's possible to pass multiple headers in on the same request, we don't want to accept them all.

Right now keystone technically enforces this because the token can only be scoped to a single project at a time, so ksm will only ever set X_PROJECT_ID to one single project.

I think we want to maintain that behavior with this passthrough.

specs/keystonemiddleware/xena/secure-rba.message:
Is the project id validated as part of this operation?

By validated, I mean checking if the project exists, the user has access to it, etc.

> I had not thought about validation yet.  I certainly think we should validate that the Project-ID provided by the client is in the same format that KSM uses for existing Project IDs.  i.e. ensure it has dashes (or doesn't have them) in the appropriate positions, and that it has the correct length, etc.
> 
> One of the use cases we've seen before is using System credentials to clean up orphaned resources after a project is removed from Keystone, so I don't think validation should include validating that the Project ID exists in Keystone.  I assume that most projects will be handle arbitrary Project IDs, given that only Keystone controls the assignment of Project IDs.
> 
> This change will only affect System-scope tokens.  As I understand the System-scope personas, they are typically cloud operators, and are consider sort-of super-users for the cloud.  This change would not validate the relationship between the system-scope token and the provided project ID.  The assumption is that a user with a valid system-scoped token inherently has access to all project IDs (including already deleted IDs).

++

Not having strict validation of the project ID makes this really useful for cleaning up stale resources. It was the main reason for not implementing strict validation.

We should however completely ignore/sanitize this header if the token is project-scoped (detailed on the next line).

I had not thought about validation yet.  I certainly think we should validate that the Project-ID provided by the client is in the same format that KSM uses for existing Project IDs.  i.e. ensure it has dashes (or doesn't have them) in the appropriate positions, and that it has the correct length, etc.

One of the use cases we've seen before is using System credentials to clean up orphaned resources after a project is removed from Keystone, so I don't think validation should include validating that the Project ID exists in Keystone.  I assume that most projects will be handle arbitrary Project IDs, given that only Keystone controls the assignment of Project IDs.

This change will only affect System-scope tokens.  As I understand the System-scope personas, they are typically cloud operators, and are consider sort-of super-users for the cloud.  This change would not validate the relationship between the system-scope token and the provided project ID.  The assumption is that a user with a valid system-scoped token inherently has access to all project IDs (including already deleted IDs).

++

This is important for making sure project users can't circumvent the authorization of their token to work on other projects.

+1
